Author: @TheRealSniperTf2
Comment: I enjoyed the song and it is built to the brim with truths about our society. A lot of people, from my experience, likes to formulate a thought based on information they learned without grabbing the concept that all information received isn't 100% revealed. As time progresses, incremental information will be discovered if the individual is vigilant and ready to absorb the information they are oblivious of noticing from their previous experience. Most people, like myself, prefer not to wait and would rather be noticed now versus being noticed some time in the future. People who put contemplative thought with the content they create (e.g. books, movies, etc.) release their media weeks, months, and maybe a year before they release their content for public viewing; yet people without the experience of being patient and will reply based on their current life situation and hopefully learn from their actions if it is a mistake. Their are two common phrases I'm feeling is relatable with my perception trying to gain fame and/or notoriety (clout): "players going to play" and "any publicity is good publicity".

Author: @shanadavis3001
Comment:
I will admit my bias because I‚Äôve been watching Colleens YouTube videos for almost 6 years now for context I never really liked Miranda Sings. I‚Äôve frankly never watched Miranda sings content unless it was for Colleen because I liked Colleen. I always loved their family‚Äôs channels and I watched Rachel, Colleen, and sometimes Chris. The whole Ballinger family that‚Äôs what I grew up with. Only recently had I started watching Colleens Vlogs less consistently Because I‚Äôve been busy with college. However, when all of this came out about Colleen a few years ago, I remember believing the person that said it and when Colleen originally addressed it everyone universally came to the understanding that she had made a mistake. The irony is all of this drama that‚Äôs coming back up is it is the same thing that people tried to cancel her with years ago. Now, by no means, am I trying to justify any of her actions, but what I‚Äôm saying is for this video specifically, I appreciated the apology. I have grown up, feeling like I‚Äôve known Colleen and known her personality, and she always turns to art when she doesn‚Äôt know how else to express herself. that‚Äôs some thing I quite liked about her because I end up doing the same thing in my personal life. The point I‚Äôm trying to make here is this apology is perfect for her in my opinion because this is an example of who Colleen is and how she deals with problems. I think it‚Äôs beautiful frankly, when an artist pours their heart into their work. I know some are saying that they would prefer for her to have been more professional in this video, but contrary to popular belief, when all of this came up years ago, she did address all of this and made a formal apology years ago. So now when people are bringing up the past again and trying to cancel her with the same old thing, I think this is a perfect way to respond and I understand if you disagree that‚Äôs all right. I could be wrong, and I could be blinded by my own nostalgia but it‚Äôs my opinion. Colleen if you happen to see this comment, just know that one of your fans has forgiven you, and still loves you.‚ù§


Also, just bring a little bit more perspective into this. I really don‚Äôt appreciate you guys calling her a pedophile because I am a sexual assault victim. I was raped by a 30 year old man when I was six years old he was a pedophile. Colleen making a few out of taste jokes and weird comments does not make her a pedophile. Please don‚Äôt label people with such horrific terms when they haven‚Äôt done anything to deserve it.

Author: @catiebug1011
Comment:
Seems like people forget there are two sides to every story...
Whether you have a platform or not, NO ONE deserves the amount of hate both sides have received.
People can heal from trauma privately instead of making it the entire internet's business. Getting revenge & trying to tear someone's life & reputation apart from someone who hurt you DOESN'T provide long term healing. Instant gratification, yes. But not healing.
If you've suffered from any sort of trauma & expect everyone to feel for you, yet you turn around & hurt the person who hurt you back, you are just as guilty of the person who caused you harm.
Everyone is responsible for their own healing.
And everyone deserves to move on & gain healing.
Leave Colleen alone.
Leave those affected by Colleen's mistakes alone.
Stick around for her content, or leave if she upsets you.
Just quit spreading hate.
And actually have the strength to walk away from what brings you down instead of arming yourselves with pitchforks.
Whether you've made horrible mistakes or not, you deserve healing.
And you deserve peace.
But no one can give you peace.
That's YOUR responsibility.
Not anyone else's.

Author: @KristinReneeCreative
Comment: Colleen I hope you‚Äôre doing ok. Just know you do have people out there who still want the best for you. You have made me laugh for years, gave me happiness as a depressed tween with no friends, helped others in their journeys to stardom, are accepting of the loser kids and gay kids and weird theater and art kids, outcasted kids, poured your heart into your work, prioritized your fans over your own health many times, you‚Äôre talented, and seemingly a wonderful mother, sister, daughter and wife. The way people have berated you, threatened you, and body shammed you over this is so vile and toxic. If the goal for this was accountability, all of those other things didn‚Äôt have to happen. This was a smear campaign. I don‚Äôt argue with there being inappropriate jokes made, I don‚Äôt want to diminish other people feelings about their experiences. This whole situation to me has been more about hurting and humiliating you and tearing apart your character with irreversible allegations that aren‚Äôt always presented in a truthful way. Calling someone‚Äôs groomer is a very serious and legally punishable thing and implies sexual abuse/relationships or other illegal activity with underage people. It‚Äôs not just talking to, joking, interacting with and being friendly with young people or every celebrity, Daily vlogger, YouTuber, Tiktoker, influencer would be considered a groomer. The YouTube community was really just beginning in 2012 and most of these YouTubers we know now had ever had experience on the platform or even much with the internet/social media altogether. MySpace was the first real ‚Äúsocial media‚Äù and it was very common for larger accounts to communicate with ‚Äòfans‚Äô of all ages in groups and messages and pen pals with younger people like an older/younger sister type relationship. That was how this generation of YouTubers grew up on the internet. Having boundaries with internet followers wasn‚Äôt something they knew they needed until they blew up enough that they had probably already crossed the boundaries most have in place today. How are you supposed to know the limitations as an internet famous person if no one had ever been internet famous before? The jokes Colleen/Miranda have made are sometimes inappropriate or even bad taste but never with ill intent never with the intention to coerce, manipulate, or groom.

Author: @reinaprocee
Comment:
I'm trying to understand this timeline of events...
Three years ago she was accused of inappropriate contact with underage fans. One in particular came out and made a video. She took accountability and apologized for her inappropriate choices and has grown and changed since then.
Meanwhile the person who made a video was doxed, bullied and harassed.
Now more corroborating evidence about her inappropriate contact has come to light and people want her to apologize again? I don't understand that. She has already apologized. If anything it's the people who bullied that one person who came out with the allegations that should apologize.

I think that maybe singing this wasn't the best move, but she is a human and people are emotional and flawed and that's kinda ok. I don't know what glowing saint person you want to see on here, but I always felt like she was honest about her missteps and mistakes and took strides to learn from them.

I'm 40 and it would kill me if people still judged me based on who I was 15 years ago. Anyways. That's my two cents.

Comment: I know a hurt, angry, frustrated heart when I hear one. It‚Äôs not wrong to come to your own defense, it just might not hold the weight you want it to. When I was a teenager my dad told me ‚Äúdon‚Äôt do good things that look bad‚Äù because regardless of my thoughts or intentions going into things, what will be addressed is what was done. That learning to align my intentions with proper actions is a way to create boundaries of respect for myself and for the people I interact with. I can‚Äôt imagine the magnitude of learning lessons publicly online where every mistake can be brought up for all of time. I myself am far from perfect and when my soul is heavy with my own shortcomings I often turn to the quote ‚ÄúI hope you live a life you‚Äôre proud of. And if you are not, I hope you have the strength to start all over again‚Äù. I don‚Äôt wish you pain but in the face of this storm, if you don‚Äôt survive the train wreck, I do hope you find a new life on the other side. There are few people with your experience that could be the catalyst and help guide places like YouTube towards adopting policies and practices that could set better boundaries for underage kids

Author: @FrangipaniGirl251
Comment:
And for all those people who claim to be hurt or want to say a bad opinion. Should people take accountability for their mistakes and change? Yes. Was choosing to do this via a song maybe not ideal for some people? Maybe. Does her doing this make her previous mistakes ok? No. But she has said sorry. It may not be in the way you want but she said it. She also has changed.

Imagine you make a mistake - could be really bad. You might initially recognise it or maybe you don‚Äôt cause it wasn‚Äôt your intention. Then you have millions of people give their opinion on either the truth or lies that were spread. People insult you, tear you down. You would be crushed.

She is a person. People have to answer for mistakes, yes. But no one deserves millions of people to berate and curse them and make them feel horrible. Just let her be. Let her recover from the online attacks.

I believe she is a good person who learns from her mistakes. People are entitled to their own views and opinions but if you have them and they are going to hurt people, think before you talk/type.

Thinking of you Colleen üíê

Comment: Colleen, I'm a long time fan and I still enjoy your content. I hope my words can give you some peace in this really isolating moment in your life. I can't even begin to imagine how difficult this has all been for you. It's not my job, or anyone's job to judge or condemn you for your actions, accused actions, or really anything. I'm not sure if you are a believer in God and I don't mean to make this religious, but my intention is to give you strength here. God is the only one to judge you in life and while the voices of media and those close to you are loudly pointing their fingers at you. Please remember something it's all forgivable. You aren't a bad person or a horrific person because of your mistake. Just learn from them. I think you're a beautiful and talented human. An amazing mother who has 3 very lucky babies. You are human and as my sister in Christ I love you and I have pain seeing the world pull you to pieces. Stay strong, find strength in prayer. I promise you it helps. Keep family close and just stay away from media. I'm sure the crows we'll find someone else to attack soon enough. Keep your head up, shine bright, and remember there is nothing that isn't forgivable in the eyes of God as long as you seek that forgiveness and learn. Sending you love and honestly a really big hug because I'm sure you need one. ‚ù§

Author: @tinapelletier4788
Comment:
Colleen,

I have been watching you for years. I have enjoyed you, your family, and truly feel like I'm a part of your life. When the accusations came out, I was utterly confused. None of it made sense. It didn't fit the Colleen that I know and it didn't seem to add up in my mind as the accusations seemed to be far fetched. Whether there can be some truth to any of them, is none of our business. That said, there are two sides to every story and even then, there's still more story.

You are an incredible inspiration to others. Your kindness, your realness, your laughter, your humor, your hair - every little bit about you makes you REAL. So many people on the internet try to be someone they are not and you aren't like that. These people who are attacking your character and reputation, don't know the real you. It can be argued that none of us really do, but I believe that a person's true motives can be discerned early on and you don't deserve to be silenced, to wither away, to feel this pain and anguish, or to have this level of total disgust and disdain thrown your way.

Keep pushing through, love. Do not lose your spark, your joy, your creativity, your realness. Don't let others' negativity cloud your sun.

I don't comment much, but know you have support in your corner - even if it doesn't seem like you do at times. ‚ù§
